maml:description.maml:para: Copies files from C:\Windows\system32\certsrv\CertEnroll to CDP/AIA repository. Crt files with server name in file name will be renamed to a sane name.
Local repository path to copy files to
Choose file type to copy: "crl", "crt", or "all".
Choose file type to copy: "crl", "crt", or "all".
Local repository path to copy files to

dev:remarks.maml:para: This copies all .crt and .crl files from C:\Windows\System32\Certsrv\CertEnroll to C:\ADCS\Web\Repository. .crt files will be renamed to the Common name in the certificate Subject field.

command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> {{ Add example code here }}

maml:description.maml:para: Install and configure an ADCS based CA.
This cmdlet will 1. Install ADCS role 2. Create local directories for ADCS content 3. Create CAPolicy.inf and copy to C:\Windows 4. Configure CA and generate CA cert or cert request
If this is a sub CA, get the signed CA cert from superior CA and install it with the Install-ZPkiCaCertificate cmdlet.
Next step is typically running Set-ZPkiCaPostInstallConfig.
Distinguished name suffix for CA certificate Subject
Assurance policy name, used for Autodetect of Assurance policy.
CSP or KSP provider to use for key storage.

Default CA type is Enterprise root, so appropriate PathLength is 0 (meaning no sub CA can be issued) Valid input for PathLength is an integer >= 0, or 'None' to remove constraint. PathLength = None and EnableBasicConstraints = $True will still include the attribute in the cert.
OID strings to include in EKU section
Require admin interaction on each key use.
For a domain joined CA server we can determine the OID to use if AssurancePolicyName is given and such a policy has been created in AD already.
Enableds Basic Constraints extension in CA certificate. Defaults to true.
Include All Issuance Policy in CA certificate
Include an Assurance policy in CA certificate. Requires Autodetect or policy definition using appropriate parameters.
If reinstalling ADCS this parameter may be needed
If reinstalling ADCS this parameter may be needed
If reinstalling ADCS this parameter may be needed
By default policy entries are disallowed in root certificates. Include this parameter to force inclusion of policy in root cert.
Require admin interaction on each key use.
Assurance policy name, used for Autodetect of Assurance policy.
For a domain joined CA server we can determine the OID to use if AssurancePolicyName is given and such a policy has been created in AD already.
Distinguished name suffix for CA certificate Subject
CSP or KSP provider to use for key storage.
OID strings to include in EKU section
Enableds Basic Constraints extension in CA certificate. Defaults to true.
Include All Issuance Policy in CA certificate
Include an Assurance policy in CA certificate. Requires Autodetect or policy definition using appropriate parameters.
If reinstalling ADCS this parameter may be needed
If reinstalling ADCS this parameter may be needed
If reinstalling ADCS this parameter may be needed

Default CA type is Enterprise root, so appropriate PathLength is 0 (meaning no sub CA can be issued) Valid input for PathLength is an integer >= 0, or 'None' to remove constraint. PathLength = None and EnableBasicConstraints = $True will still include the attribute in the cert.
By default policy entries are disallowed in root certificates. Include this parameter to force inclusion of policy in root cert.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Install-ZPkiCa -CaCommonName "ZampleWorks PKI v1 Issuing CA" -CaDnSuffix = "O = ZampleWorks, C = SE"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will install an Enterprise Root CA with Subject built from supplied CN and DN suffix.

maml:description.maml:para: Installs a signed CA certificate for this CA

This is used when installing a subordinate CA. The installation generates a Certificate Signing Request file that needs to get signed by another CA. Use this cmdlet to install the resulting signed certificate.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> {{ Add example code here }}

maml:description.maml:para: Generates a HTML index file for CDP/AIA repository

This cmdlet will generate a helpful HTML page containing web links to all CA certificates and CRL files in the given directory (SourcePath). You can include Javascript/CSS files of your choosing by using the CssFiles/JsFiles parameters. You can generate a default CSS file with the New-ZPkiRepoCssFile.

Recommendation: create both binary and PEM versions of each cert in the source directory. Follow this naming standard: cacert.crt and cacert.pem.crt. If you do the pem versions will be included on the same table row.
The cmdlet assumes the following layout of files in the generated HTML: -> index.html -> Repository/ -> cacert.crt -> cacert.pem.crt
This directory will be scanned for crt/cer/crl files. It is assumed that files will be in a subdirectory named 'Repository' relative to the index.html file.
Style sheet to include in html
HTML header for the CA certs section
HTML header for the CA CRLs section
HTML header for the CA certs section
HTML header for the CA CRLs section
Style sheet to include in html
This directory will be scanned for crt/cer/crl files. It is assumed that files will be in a subdirectory named 'Repository' relative to the index.html file.

maml:description.maml:para: Add/remove CDP and AIA URL configuration

the Fqdn and Path parameters are for building a complete HTTP URI. For example, $HttpCdpFqdn = my.server.com $HttpCdpPath = "Repository" the generated URI will start with "http://my.server.com/Repository"
FQDN for accessing CDP over HTTP
HTTP path for accessing CDP over HTTP
FQDN for accessing AIA over HTTP
HTTP path for accessing AIA over HTTP

Removes all CDP entries. Will always leave default file publish path C:\Windows\system32\certsrv\CertEnroll
